distributions 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

    GaussianRandomVariable object

    GaussianRandomVariable.Rd

    Defines a Normal random variable. It uses in the backend all functions that defines a Gaussian random variable. As other the other definitions in distributions this is an R6 object. Tha parametrization used is from a $$X \sim \mathsf{Normal}(\mu, \sigma)\,,$$ where \(\mu\) and \(\sigma\) are the mean and standar deviation, respectively.

    Note:

    All random variables in distributions are defined as R6 objects. The fields (referenced below) are needed for objects of R6::R6Class. In our context these are what defines which specific instance of a random variable is used. That is, the public fields are the parameters of the random variable \(\theta \in \mathbb{R}^p\), for some \(p\).

    Super class

    distributions::ContinuousRandomVariable -> Gaussian

    Public fields

    mean

    (double)
    the center of the distribution, \(\mu\).

    sd

    (positive)
    the dispersion around the mean, \(\sigma\).

    Methods

    Public methods

    • GaussianRandomVariable$new()

    • GaussianRandomVariable$sample()

    • GaussianRandomVariable$density()

    Method new()

    Generates a Gaussian ContinuousRandomVariable object with specified mean (mean) and standard deviation (sd).

    Usage

    GaussianRandomVariable$new(mean = 0, sd = 1)

    Arguments

    mean

    the center of the distribution.

    sd

    the dispersion around the center of the distribution.

    Method sample()

    Generates random variables using the stats::rnorm() function.

    Usage

    GaussianRandomVariable$sample(nsamples = 1)

    Arguments

    nsamples

    (integer) the number of random numbers being generated that behaves like the random variables.

    Method density()

    Evaluates the density function using the stats::pnorm() function.

    Usage

    GaussianRandomVariable$density(x, log = TRUE)

    Arguments

    x

    (array) to evaluate the density function.

    log

    (Boolean) indicates if we are evaluating the log-density.
